Articles.Content: I noticed that the new wheels in .20 seem to cause rovers to shake uncontrollably. So I tried to "fix" them by messing with the config file. This was the result:
This is the most kerbal way I've seen for a rover to drive around XD

Yeah, I had one like that too.

Per KasperVld, it has to do with starting the craft with a physicsless part, such as a girder. Evidently it's a known bug.

Not a bad way to get around though!
Spider-rover, spider rover, does whatever a spider-rover does...

I launched another Eve Rover mission, but this time, instead of landing the Rover on Eve, I went to Gilly, and forgot about the superlight gravity...result...

Here is the lander tumbling end-over-end, with its "braking block". It almost never wanted to stop and settle...well, almost.

After I extended my PV's, it did somehow finally managed to settle down. If you take a good look in the distance, to the left of the rover, the "braking block" (now debris) also managed to settle on Gilly's surface on its own.

And here's a neat discovery I made. Even though I lacked RCS or SAS/ASAS, I still was able to somehow orient the rover by SPINNING THE WHEELS. Wow, does that mean Squad implemented gyroscopic effects? I should post a video of that.

...so after a few yaws, pitches and rolls with my new "rover wheel gyros", I tore off one of the PVs
